name: Christina Cho
content:
Christina Cho is an architect in Australia. Cho was born in Seoul, South Korea, and raised in Brisbane, Australia. Her Korean-Australian upbringing shaped how she sees the world and her architectural practice.[1]
 She is the co-organizer of Pecha Kucha nights in Brisbane.[2] She is an Accredited Green Star Professional and a LEED Design Professional. Cho started as a committee member of FutureNet. She began serving as an Advisory Board Member at the University of Queensland School of Architecture in 2013.[3] She was featured in the book Chasing the Sky: 20 Stories of Women in Architecture" by Dean Dewhirst.[4]
 She collaborated with designers on installations of public art, one of which won the Tokyo Designers Week competition. Her side projects emphasize human interaction through art and design.[1] She is a member of the Property Industry Foundation that works to combat youth homelessness.
 Cho received a Bachelor of Design Studies from the University of Queensland in 2003. Cho earned her master's degree in architecture at the University of California in Berkeley in 2006. Cho graduated from the University of Queensland in 2007 as Valedictorian with first class honors with a Bachelor of Architecture. She received a Master of Environmental Management and Sustainable Development from the University of Queensland in 2013.
 Cho is a Director at Cox Architecture in Brisbane.[5] She serves as an Adjunct Professor at the University of Queensland School of Architecture.[6] She worked on the University of Queensland Oral Health Centre, a project that won the FDG Stanley Award for Public Architecture at the Queensland Architecture Awards in 2016, as well as the Interior Architecture Award at the National Architecture Awards in 2016.
 Before her work at Cox, she worked at Donovan Hill. She has worked at HOK in San Francisco, Skycorp Developments, and Duga Architects in Seoul.
 Cho chaired the Emerging Architects and Graduate Network chapter in Queensland (2008-2010).

raw:
This article contains content that is written like an advertisement. Please help improve it by removing promotional content and inappropriate external links, and by adding encyclopedic content written from a neutral point of view. (March 2019) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)


Christina Na-Heon ChoBornSeoul, South KoreaNationalityKorean AustralianOccupationArchitectPracticeCox Architecture

Christina Cho is an architect in Australia. Cho was born in Seoul, South Korea, and raised in Brisbane, Australia. Her Korean-Australian upbringing shaped how she sees the world and her architectural practice.[1]
She is the co-organizer of Pecha Kucha nights in Brisbane.[2] She is an Accredited Green Star Professional and a LEED Design Professional. Cho started as a committee member of FutureNet. She began serving as an Advisory Board Member at the University of Queensland School of Architecture in 2013.[3] She was featured in the book Chasing the Sky: 20 Stories of Women in Architecture" by Dean Dewhirst.[4]
She collaborated with designers on installations of public art, one of which won the Tokyo Designers Week competition. Her side projects emphasize human interaction through art and design.[1] She is a member of the Property Industry Foundation that works to combat youth homelessness.

Contents

1 Education
2 Career
3 Recognition
4 Projects
5 References


Education[edit]
Cho received a Bachelor of Design Studies from the University of Queensland in 2003. Cho earned her master's degree in architecture at the University of California in Berkeley in 2006. Cho graduated from the University of Queensland in 2007 as Valedictorian with first class honors with a Bachelor of Architecture. She received a Master of Environmental Management and Sustainable Development from the University of Queensland in 2013.

Career[edit]
Cho is a Director at Cox Architecture in Brisbane.[5] She serves as an Adjunct Professor at the University of Queensland School of Architecture.[6] She worked on the University of Queensland Oral Health Centre, a project that won the FDG Stanley Award for Public Architecture at the Queensland Architecture Awards in 2016, as well as the Interior Architecture Award at the National Architecture Awards in 2016.
Before her work at Cox, she worked at Donovan Hill. She has worked at HOK in San Francisco, Skycorp Developments, and Duga Architects in Seoul.
Cho chaired the Emerging Architects and Graduate Network chapter in Queensland (2008-2010).

Recognition[edit]
Tokyo Designers Week competition (public art, ***)
Dulux Study Tour - Emerging Architect Traveling Scholarship (2011)
Queensland Emerging Architect Prize (Australian Institute of Architects, 2017)[2]
Australian Financial Review BOSS Young Executive 2018 (The Australian Financial Review BOSS Magazine, 2018)[7]
National Emerging Architect Prize (Australian Institute of Architects, 2018)[8]
Projects[edit]
Ipswich Government Office Tower in Queensland, Project Architect[9]
Kings Square commercial urban renewal development in Perth
University of Queensland Oral Health Centre

^ a b "Christina Cho awarded 2017 Queensland Emerging Architect Prize". ArchitectureAU. Retrieved 6 March 2019.

^ "Meet the new Advisory Board". School of Architecture. Retrieved 6 March 2019.

^ "New book puts spotlight on Australia's leading women in architecture". Architecture & Design. Retrieved 6 March 2019.

^ "Christina Na-Heon Cho". COX. Retrieved 6 March 2019.

^ "Our People". School of Architecture. Retrieved 6 March 2019.

^ "BOSS Young Executives 2018: meet the winners working hard for their communities". Australian Financial Review. 10 July 2018. Retrieved 6 March 2019.

^ "2018 National Prizes: National Emerging Architect Prize". ArchitectureAU. Retrieved 6 March 2019.

^ "100 Women in Property Participant Biographies: Christina Cho, Director - Cox Architecture". www.propertycouncil.com.au. Retrieved 6 March 2019.
